body.name: The Secret Life Of Sunflowers: A gripping, inspiring novel based on the true story of Johanna Bonger, Vincent van Gogh's sister-in-law
body.description: "This book draws all the emotions out of you. I went from tears to snorting with laughter. It was both lighthearted and heart breaking, yet it inspires me to live my best life! " Michelle CoxWhen Hollywood auctioneer Emsley Wilson finds her famous grandmother's diary while cleaning out her New York brownstone, the pages are full of surprises. The first surprise is, the diary isn't her grandmother's. It belongs to Johanna Bonger, Vincent van Gogh's sister-in-law.Johanna inherited Vincent van Gogh's paintings. They were all she had, and they weren't worth anything. She was a 28 year old widow with a baby in the 1800s, without any means of supporting herself, living in Paris where she barely spoke the language. Yet she managed to introduce Vincent's legacy to the world.The inspiration couldn't come at a better time for Emsley. With her business failing, an unexpected love turning up in her life, and family secrets unraveling, can she find answers in the past?"This book was so much more than I had expected, and I had high expectations... one of the most beautiful stories I've read in years." Kaela Stokes"It touched something in my soul." Audrey McDonald Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Must Read
reviews.reviewText: History, art, inspiration, wit and a little women’s lib thrown in. You’re drawn in thinking you know a little of the Van Gogh story and find out there’s a whole story behind the story. And it took a woman to make sure his art lived on and literally wasn’t burned or painted over. Ah, and then there’s the hard to resist love story ….A must read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Theme: If she can do it; I can do it
reviews.reviewText: I would say that most Americans from high school on up know who Vincent Van Gogh is: The creator of some of the world’s most beautiful paintings (Starry, Starry Night; Sunflowers to name a few) or the mad painter who cut off his ear and gave it to a prostitute as a sign of affection. There have been hundreds of books, movies, songs and tv shows that give readers/watchers an insight to this complicated man.But this novel gives readers a new perspective, When Vincent dies in 1890 by suicide (gunshot to the chest), he leaves his paintings to his brother, Theo, and his wife, Johanna. After Theo dies in 1891, the paintings are left to Johanna. And Johanna is the subject of this powerful novel with the theme of inspiring women.Even before Theo’s death from general paresis of insane in 1891, Johanna was trying to establish Vincent reputation in the art world. True she the money that his paintings would bring, but in the 1890s, women did not have many ways to earn a living, Plus she had her son to provide for.Now then, this book takes on a dual narrative that is not quite interesting as Johanna’s story, yet Johanna becomes an inspiration to Emsley Wilson, who is the fictional granddaughter of Violet Valkyrie, a woman who was also a well-known artist. Emsley lives and works in LA as a Hollywood auctioneer. Violet had Johanna’s diary, which is the catalyst for the novel when Violet has her look into her blue box at the back of her closet and encourages Emsley to read it.Bottom line: It is because of Johanna’s unrelenting ambition to make Vincent a household name that it is. Throw in some 2022 shenanigans from Emsley’s ex-boyfriend and best friend to take her business and an unexpected romance that create such a riveting. For me, the first four chapters were rather slow, but once I started Chapter 5, I couldn’t put it down. Therefore, The Secret Life of Sunflowers gets 5 out of 5 stars in Julie’s world.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Vincent Van Gogh
reviews.reviewText: Very well written. The author did a great job researching. Some years ago I read one of his biographies and there was some mention of his sister-in-law. It’s amazing how determined Jo was to get the recognition for his work, even though he had passed before this happened.. Great read. I recommend it to any art enthusiast or just a passion for a good story..

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: The story was so interesting and inspiring. I knew a little about Vincent Van Gogh, but really not a thing about his struggles or life. I actually took a break from reading to do a little research on his life. The author appears to have really based the story on real life. I had never heard of Johanna or Theo but got to know them through the story. I think I will read something more by this author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not sure if gripping is the right word..
reviews.reviewText: I loved the history of the book. I didn’t know about her and not much of Van Gogh honestly. I was not a fan of the present day main character though. I enjoyed the backstory with the grandma, but I could’ve done without the love story completely. It wasn’t necessary and I felt it took away from the historical events. I was a bit disappointed as I heard such great things about this book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: We've all entered Vincent Van Gough's world through his art, countless tales in school, or passing comments over coffee. His brilliance is an immortal thread of society rightfully so. This story gives us a glimpse at him as a man who was loved deeply in a way that we often only skim over. Here we see him through the eyes of his sister-in-law and brother, simultaneously with a more modern story of three generations of his great nieces and their journies. The author marries these stories well as you jump back and forth through time.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars So informative and well written
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed reading about the strong women in this book, which was a recurring theme. While the men were strong and talented and overbearing in the case of Trey, it was the women who made everything happen. Johanna refusing to quit was mirrored by Emsley strength and persistence and refusal to quit I. Her own endeavors.Well written and fast moving.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I wasn't sure what to expect when I first started reading this book, but I was pleasantly surprised. It grabbed me from the beginning and never let go. I found the characters delightful. Yes, there are a few loose ends that weren't touched on such as the fact that Theo actually died from syphilis, but overall, I was truly impressed and thoroughly enjoyed the book. I found myself looking forward to reading it and having a hard time putting it down. I highly recommend it.

J'ai acheté ce livre à cause d'une émission de tv au sujet de Vincent Van Gogh qui mentionnait sa belle-soeur, Johanna. J'ai voulu en savoir davantage. J'ai extrêmement aimé ce livre. Il se lit vite. Il est très intéressant. Il y manque seulement des photos des peintures qui sont mentionnées. Je vous en souhaite la joie de sa lecture.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Not really the kind of book I usually go for but something about it pulled me in. My husband is an artist, so I know about the ups and downs, the drama and the passion... Loved it!
I had no idea about the story of Van Gogh and his brother Theo's history.What a remarkable daughter in law and wife. Her legacy is outstanding.

The pace is fast. The twin story lines fully engaging and fun to read. This author has some 'chops', is spikey and can be fun, but to be taken seriously as an author of historical fiction, she needs a good editor/publishing house assistance, in my view. I hope she gets picked up by a publisher. Or that she moves on to the movie or TV series worlds where her style could soar.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book is an inspiring tale of two women separated by several generations and continents, living through tough times.The links to the historical facts about Vincent and Theo van Gogh are fascinating and the way the author moves effortlessly into the present day story left me zipping through the chapters to get from one era to the next.
